awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  A Deep-learning-based Chatbot and Personalized Recommendations: Application to Nutrition
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to advance the health and welfare of the American public. Obesity among American adults has risen from 12% in 1990 to over 40% today, leading to an estimated medical cost of $260 billion in 2016, according to the Center for Disease Control (CDC). According to the National Institute for Health (NIH), 70% of American adults were overweight or obese in 2014. In 2013, American adults were spending $60 billion annually on weight loss, according to US News & World Report. A 2008 American Journal of Preventive Medicine study showed that those who kept daily food journals lost twice as much weight as those who did not. However, existing diet tracking methods are often too time-consuming for maintaining long-term weight loss. A personalized artificial intelligence (AI) chatbot could make food logging fun and easy, benefitting millions of Americans who are trying to lose weight and furthering knowledge on spoken dialogue systems.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will advance knowledge in the field of spoken dialogue systems in several ways. First, the project establishes a new research area by noting that AI and spoken dialogue systems have yet to be applied to nutrition. Typically, conversational agents focus on factual question answering or tasks such as flight booking, but there is an opportunity to leverage big data for learning relationships between diet and health. Second, this project will develop a neural generative chatbot model with memory, demonstrating the benefit of personalized conversational interactions with intelligent agents that remember the history of conversations and personal details about the user. While manually writing chatbot responses ensures more control over the output, the drawback is that the responses are less interesting, diverse, and flexible. This work proposes generative Transformers in order to generate more realistic, human-like responses and knowledge graphs as a novel method for remembering the conversation and diet tracking history of each user for personalized feedback. Finally, this project proposes the application of causal inference, often used for medical diagnosis, to the new, challenging task of predicting which foods lead to outcomes such as gut symptoms, weight loss, or muscle building.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
The following were the major outcomes of our Phase I SBIR project:

  1. Built a novel nutrition chatbot: This project yielded the creation of a novel LLM chatbot, with memory of the user’s previous conversation history, that can log foods, ask followup questions about quantities and brands, log weight, answer nutrition fact questions, compare the healthiness of two foods, and provide food recommendations.
  2. Implemented personalized food recommendations: Recommendations are critical to the success of a nutrition startup today since users want to know which food they should eat next. Most existing diet tracking companies do not give advice, or rely on human nutritionists, which is expensive and does not scale. As a result of this project, our system now provides automated, personalized diet advice.

Intellectual Merit

Advanced NLP techniques were implemented using a Transformer-based LLM to predict user intents such as food logging, food recommendations, asking for nutrition information, comparing different foods, and weight logging. For intent prediction, we used a few-shot prompting technique to predict user intent for food logging based on patterns in past chat data. Multiple approaches were also taken for conversational dialogue-based slot filling. Based on the user's intent, such as logging a food entry, we collect relevant form-based slot values through a conversational dialogue, such as the type of food, brand, and quantity, similar to a nutritionist asking questions. We utilized models that were fine-tuned on JSON-based entity filling through conversational dialogues and ReACT-based slot filling. The model ensures that all required slots and entities are filled in a specific format before executing the final intent. For example, for food logging, it only searches the USDA food database for the best matches once the food description, brand, and quantity slots are filled by the LLM. The dialogue continues until the input data matches the specified schema.

Our application supports various intents to achieve the desired outcomes and features. For example, when we collect food logging data, we use an embedding-based USDA food database search. To provide automated, personalized food recommendations, we first calculate a user's Basal Metabolic Rate (BMR) using a user’s sex, weight, height, and age. Then the Harris-Benedict equation uses the BMR multiplied by an additional factor determined by an individual’s activity level (i.e., sedentary, lightly active, moderately active, very active, or extremely active). The result of these calculations determines a user’s Total Daily Energy Expenditure (TDEE), which we use to represent a user's total caloric intake. Based on these calculations, we can determine the total amount of protein, carbohydrates, and fat that an individual should consume for a given day. These values are ratioed into their respective amounts that would constitute a healthy portion for breakfast, lunch, or dinner and fed as parameters to search the USDA database for an acceptable meal depending on the given time of the request. The chatbot then summarizes these recommendations into a format that is easy for users to understand. For safety purposes, the LLM only rephrases and summarizes data retrieved by our proprietary API.

We evaluated our system on 1,000 human Amazon Mechanical Turk workers. Overall, the rating of 4.13 out of 5, and intent prediction and food logging scores over 90%, indicate that our system is working well. However, work is still needed in Phase II to improve the food recommender system so that recommended foods are healthy.

Broader Impacts

Our technology has the potential to improve public health and personalized nutrition, enhancing research accuracy and efficiency, and strengthening compliance and study participation. Our platform addresses a critical need in academic research by providing an efficient and accurate method for tracking study participants' nutritional intake. Traditional methods involving manual recording or surveys often result in incomplete or inaccurate data. Our technology ensures a higher quality of data, paving the way for more reliable research outcomes, especially in studies related to conditions such as obesity, Alzheimer's disease, heart disease, kidney disease, and diabetes. Improved dietary habits can lead to better public health outcomes, reducing the burden of diet-related diseases and promoting overall well-being. Our platform addresses the challenge of study participants adhering to specific diets by providing a user-friendly interface that seamlessly integrates into their daily routines. The chatbot and personalized recommendations create a more engaging experience, increasing participant compliance and reducing the burden on both researchers and participants. As MealMate contributes to a deeper understanding of the intricate relationship between diet and health, it becomes a catalyst for proactive health management, ultimately fostering a healthier and happier society across the United States.


Last Modified: 04/16/2024
Modified by: Eric Speck
